subject: Re: New poll for Read_Alphabet
msgSnippet: There is also an m17n layout in the input section that s compatible with any of the Linux input methods that have an installable m17n extension. It may be
messageBody:
There is also an m17n layout in the input section that's compatible with any of the Linux input methods that have an installable m17n extension. It may be useful in recent versions of the big distros that have switched to I-bus. There are detailed instructions an how to get layouts like it working at http://shavian.wordpress.com/ (warning, in Unicode Shavian). The layout is set to the Kingsley Unicode font (which I think can still be found here). I don't know if Kingsley and Thoth use the same codepoints. I can finally test that now, thanks.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Myzomela" <anthonydh@...> wrote:
>
>
> Hello JF,
>
> In Linux, you can use a tool called SCIM to map the keyboard. Look in the files area for scim-qs.tar.gz, which contains the map files and some instructions which I put together a while ago.
>
> There is a fairly good font called ThothUni which uses the Unicode private use area. (In fact the "read me" file in the tarball uses it.) Unfortunately it is no longer hosted where it used to be, so I've just uploaded it to Files > Fonts > ThothFonts.tar.gz.
>
> Anthony Hagan
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Jean-François Colson" <jf@> wrote:
> >
> > Hello
> >
> > I had some problems with my Yahoogroups account and I cannot access to
> > it for 24 hours. That's why I'll answer here. Another reason is that the
> > question is not as easily âanswerableâ as you might think.
> >
> > First, the Quikscript alphabet has not yet been included in Unicode.
> > Hence it is not possible to âwrite Unicode Quickscriptâ at all.
> >
> > Perhaps there's a font somewhere with QS in the Private Use Area. If so,
> > I'd like a link to download it. Is it complete with all the half
> > letters, variant forms, x-ligatures and Scottish ll and ch letters?
> >
> > If such a font exists and provided that I know where to find it, I could
> > download it and install it on my computers, on Linux and on Windows. I
> > have no Mac now.
> >
> > The only problem, very easily solvable on some systems, is the lack of
> > suitable keyboard driver.
> > There are programs to create keyboard drivers.
> > On Windows, you can use the Microsoft Keyboard Layout Creator (MSKLC),
> > which is free, the Windows Driver Kit (WDK), Tavultesoft Keyman or a few
> > other programs.
> > On Mac OS, there's a useful program called Ukelele.
> > On Linux, you'd have to create and/or modify some configuration files.
> > That's not very difficult once you have spend a little time to
> > understand how that works.
> > I read that's more problematic on Haiku, but I've never tried that
> > system.
> >
> > JF
> >
> >
> >
> > On 20 juin 11 00:16 <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> >
> > > Enter your vote today! A new poll has been created for the
> > > Read_Alphabet group:
> > >
> > > Can you write Unicode Quickscript on your computer?
> > >
> > > o Yes
> > > o No
> > >
> > >
> > > To vote, please visit the following web page:
> > > <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/surveys?id=3051193>
> > >
> > > Note: Please do not reply to this message. Poll votes are
> > > not collected via email. To vote, you must go to the Yahoo! Groups
> > > web site listed above.
> > >
> > > Thanks!
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >

> > >

> > >
> >
>
